Detailed Description

A three-dimensional point.

This class can be used to interchangeably represent either a point in three-dimensional space or a vector in three-dimensional space. It includes many of the functions that one would expect for such things, including addition, subtraction, scalar multiplication, dot product, cross product, unit vector calculation, and magnitude calculation.

Definition at line 15 of file point.h.

Point3::Point3 ( std::string  pointStr  ) 

Special constructor.

This constructor is only used in the Mesh class.

It takes in a string of a specific type, usually the type that is given in standard .obj files. This string is of the form "v* n1 n2 n3", where '*' is a character (or nothing), and n1, n2, and n3 are all doulbles. If pointStr is not of the proper format, then it throws an error to the error class and sets loadError to true, then uses the default constructor.

Parameters:
pointStr is the string to turn into a point.

This function does not edit the value of *this.

Point3 Point3::cross ( const Point3 &  tocross  ) 

Cross this vector with another.

The cross product is calculated as the traditional cross product of two vectors in three-dimensional space. One possible application for this is that the cross product of two vectors which are not parallel is a vector perpendicular to both of the originals, oriented using the right-hand-rule. Note that for cross products, the order in which two vectors are crossed can affect the result.

This function does not edit the value of *this.

Parameters:
tocross is the vector to be crossed with this one.
Returns:
returns the cross product of these two vectors.

Definition at line 237 of file point.cpp.

00238 {
00239     return Point3((y*tocross.z - z*tocross.y), -(x*tocross.z - z*tocross.x), (x*tocross.y - y*tocross.x));
00240 }

double Point3::dot ( const Point3 &  a,
const Point3 &  b 
) [static]

Static function to dot two vectors.

The dot product is calculated as the traditional dot product of two vectors in three-dimensional space. This function is static because it is usually clearer to use Point3::dot(a,b) than to use a.dot(b).

Parameters:
a is the first vector to be dotted.
b is the second vector to be dotted.
Returns:
returns the dot product of a and b.

Definition at line 252 of file point.cpp.

00253 {
00254         return a.x*b.x + a.y*b.y + a.z*b.z;
00255 }

Point3 Point3::cross ( const Point3 &  a,
const Point3 &  b 
) [static]

Static function to cross two vectors.

The cross product is calculated as the traditional cross product of two vectors in three-dimensional space. One possible application for this is that the cross product of two vectors which are not parallel is a vector perpendicular to both of the originals, oriented using the right-hand-rule. Note that for cross products, the order in which two vectors are crossed can affect the result.

Parameters:
a is the first vector to be crossed.
b is the second vector to be crossed.
Returns:
returns the cross product a x b.

double Point3::getMagSquared (  ) 

Get the magnitued of this vector squared.

This function is useful because the square root function is relatively expensive. For comparison purposes, this works much faster.

This function does not edit the value of *this.

Returns:
returns the magnitude of this vector squared.

void Point3::doVertex (  ) 

Perform a glVertex3d() call.

Simply a nice interface so that one can store vertices of an OpenGL polygon or mesh in Point3 classes. Use this function in order to perform a glVertex3d() call with the coordinates of this point as the arguments.

Definition at line 314 of file point.cpp.

00315 {
00316     glVertex3d(x,y,z);
00317 }

void Point3::doNormal (  ) 

Perform a glNormal3d() call.

Simply a nice interface so that one can store normals of an OpenGL polygon or mesh in Point3 classes. Use this function in order to perform a glNormal3d() call with the coordinates of this point as the arguments.
